definitions: send a brief electronic signal to test connection or locate a device
make a short high-pitched metallic sound when hit or struck
examples: The technician will ping the server to check network connectivity
Can you ping my phone to help me find it
The metal spoon pinged against the ceramic bowl accidentally
Raindrops ping on the tin roof during heavy storms

definitions: tie or hold someone's arms to prevent movement or escape
bind a bird's wings together to prevent it from flying away
examples: The guards had to pinion the prisoner before transport
They pinioned his arms behind his back with rope
The falconer will pinion the hawk during initial training sessions
Farmers sometimes pinion domestic geese to keep them grounded

definitions: reach or cause to reach the highest point of achievement or development
examples: Her career pinnacled when she became company CEO last year
The athlete pinnacled his performance at the Olympic Games

definitions: find or locate something with exact precision in space or position
identify or determine something with complete accuracy and specific detail
examples: Scientists can pinpoint the earthquake's epicenter using seismic data
The GPS device helps pinpoint your exact location anywhere
Doctors worked to pinpoint the cause of her symptoms
Can you pinpoint when the problem first started occurring

definitions: be the first to develop or use new methods ideas or areas
be among the first to explore or settle a new territory
examples: Marie Curie pioneered research in radioactivity and nuclear physics
The company pioneered the use of renewable energy sources
Early settlers pioneered the western territories despite many hardships
His grandparents pioneered this valley over a century ago

definitions: defeat someone by a very small margin in competition or contest
make a short high-pitched sound like a young bird chirping
examples: She pipped her rival at the finish line by milliseconds
Our team pipped theirs to win the championship title
Baby chicks pip constantly when they're hungry for food
The smoke detector pips when its battery runs low

definitions: stimulate interest or curiosity about something in an engaging way
hurt someone's pride or self-respect causing irritation or resentment
examples: The mysterious letter piqued her curiosity about family secrets
The unusual advertisement piqued my interest in the product
His dismissive comments piqued her during the important meeting
Being overlooked for promotion piqued him more than expected

definitions: lift move or throw something using a large pronged farming tool
examples: The farmers pitchfork hay into the barn loft daily
Workers pitchforked compost onto the vegetable garden beds yesterday

definitions: remove the soft spongy tissue from the center of plant stems
examples: The botanist will pith the stem before microscopic examination
You should pith the elder branches before making flutes

definitions: feel sorrow or compassion for someone's suffering misfortune or unhappiness
examples: I pity anyone who has to work such long hours
She pitied the homeless man sleeping in the cold

definitions: turn or rotate around a central point or axis smoothly
change direction strategy or focus completely in response to circumstances
examples: The basketball player pivoted quickly to avoid the defender
The door pivots on well-oiled hinges for smooth operation
The company pivoted from hardware to software development successfully
Many restaurants pivoted to delivery service during the pandemic

definitions: put up or display signs notices or posters in public places
examples: Protesters placarded the building with their demands all night
The city placarded warnings about the contaminated water supply

definitions: make someone less angry or hostile by doing something to please them
examples: She tried to placate the upset customer with a refund
The manager placated angry employees by addressing their concerns

definitions: cause continual trouble or distress to someone over extended time
affect with disease that spreads quickly through a population
examples: Financial problems have plagued the family for several years
Doubts about his decision plagued him throughout the night
The virus plagued the entire region during winter months
Locusts plagued the crops causing widespread famine last year

definitions: cover or furnish something with long flat pieces of timber
cook food especially fish on a wooden board for flavor
examples: They planked the old floor with sturdy oak boards
Workers planked the deck of the ship before painting
The chef planked the salmon on cedar for extra flavor
Native Americans traditionally planked fish over open fires outdoors

definitions: cover a wall or surface with soft mixture that hardens when dry
cover or apply something thickly or excessively all over a surface
examples: The workers will plaster the walls before painting them white
They plastered the ceiling to hide the ugly cracks
She plastered sunscreen all over her face and arms
Rain plastered his hair flat against his head completely

definitions: braid or weave strands of hair rope or similar materials together
examples: She learned to plat her daughter's hair for school
Sailors plat ropes to make them stronger and decorative

definitions: make a solemn promise or commitment to do or give something
give something as security for a loan or as guarantee
examples: The president pledged to reduce unemployment within two years
Students pledge allegiance to the flag every morning together
He pledged his house as collateral for the business loan
Members pledge monthly donations to support the charity organization

definitions: pledge or promise solemnly in a formal or ceremonial way
examples: The couple will plight their troth at the wedding ceremony
Knights would plight their loyalty to the king publicly

definitions: turn over earth with a farming tool to prepare for planting
move forward forcefully through something that resists or obstructs
examples: Farmers plough their fields every spring before planting season
The tractor ploughed the hard ground despite the drought
The ship ploughed through heavy waves during the storm
She ploughed through the dense report in one afternoon

definitions: turn over earth with a farming tool to prepare for planting
move forward forcefully through something that resists or obstructs
examples: Farmers plow their fields every spring before planting crops
The tractor plowed ten acres of land by noon
The truck plowed through deep snow to reach town
He plowed through his homework assignments before dinner time

definitions: pull out or remove something with a quick sharp movement
play a stringed instrument by pulling and releasing the strings
examples: She plucked a flower from the garden for her vase
The chef plucked feathers from the chicken before cooking
He plucked the guitar strings to create a gentle melody
Children plucked the harp strings during their music lesson

definitions: fill or block a hole gap or opening with something solid
promote or publicize something persistently in media or conversation
examples: The plumber will plug the leak with special waterproof compound
She plugged the drain to fill the bathtub with water
The author plugged her new book on every talk show
Radio stations constantly plug their upcoming concert events daily

definitions: measure the depth of water using a weighted line or device
install or repair water pipes and plumbing fixtures in buildings
examples: Sailors plumb the harbor depth before bringing in ships
Scientists plumb ocean trenches to study marine life below
He will plumb the new bathroom with copper pipes tomorrow
The contractor plumbed the entire house in just three days

definitions: spread out in a shape resembling a large feather or plume
rise up in a tall column shape like smoke or steam
examples: The peacock plumed its tail feathers during the mating display
Her dress plumed out as she spun around dancing
Smoke plumed from the factory chimney into the sky
Steam plumed from the volcanic vent throughout the day

definitions: fall or drop straight down at high speed through air or space
examples: Stock prices plummeted after the company announced bankruptcy yesterday
The eagle plummeted toward the lake to catch fish

definitions: make something fuller rounder or fatter by shaking or patting
sit or fall down heavily with full weight and little care
examples: She plumped the cushions before the guests arrived for dinner
The nurse plumped his pillows to make him more comfortable
He plumped down on the sofa after a long day
The children plumped into bed completely exhausted from playing

definitions: steal goods from a place or person typically using force during war
examples: Vikings would plunder coastal villages for gold and supplies
The army plundered the conquered city taking everything valuable

definitions: jump or dive quickly and energetically into water or downward
push or thrust something or someone quickly into a substance or situation
examples: The swimmer plunged into the pool from the high board
Stock markets plunged following news of the economic crisis
She plunged the vegetables into boiling water for blanching
The power outage plunged the city into complete darkness

definitions: work steadily at one's trade or business with regular effort
travel regularly over a route especially for commercial purposes
examples: The carpenter plied his trade for over forty years
Street vendors ply their wares in the busy market
Ferries ply between the island and mainland every hour
Taxis ply the route from airport to city center

definitions: produce or form seed cases on plants especially legumes like peas
examples: The pea plants pod heavily in warm weather with moisture
These bean varieties pod earlier than traditional types grown here

definitions: make or distribute digital audio files available online for downloading or streaming
examples: She podcasts about true crime stories every week online
Many comedians now podcast to reach wider audiences directly

definitions: balance or hold something in a carefully controlled position steadily
hold oneself or something in readiness for action or movement
examples: The waiter poised the tray carefully on one hand
She poised herself on the edge of the diving board
The cat poised itself ready to pounce on prey
He poised his pen above the paper before writing

definitions: give someone a substance that causes illness or death when absorbed
contaminate or make something harmful or toxic to living things
examples: Someone tried to poison the king with arsenic-laced wine
The villain poisoned her rival using a deadly plant extract
Industrial waste poisoned the river killing all fish downstream
Lead paint can poison children who eat the chips

definitions: push or jab someone or something with a finger or pointed object
search or look around in a casual or nosy way
examples: Don't poke your sister while she's trying to concentrate
He poked the fire with a stick to stir it
She likes to poke around antique shops on weekends
Stop poking into my personal business and private matters

definitions: make something smooth and shiny by rubbing with cloth or substance
improve or refine something by making small changes and corrections
examples: She polished the silver until it gleamed like new
He polished his shoes every morning before work
The author polished her manuscript through several careful revisions
Students polish their presentation skills through repeated practice

definitions: dance a lively dance with hopping steps in duple time
examples: The couple polkaed around the dance floor with energy
My grandparents still polka at their anniversary party yearly

definitions: transfer pollen to a plant to enable fertilization and reproduction
examples: Bees pollinate flowers as they collect nectar for honey
Farmers sometimes hand pollinate crops to ensure good yields

definitions: contaminate water air or place with harmful or poisonous substances
examples: Factories pollute rivers by dumping chemicals into the water
Car exhaust fumes pollute the air in crowded cities

definitions: strike or beat someone or something repeatedly with fists or object
examples: The boxer pommeled his opponent with rapid punches repeatedly
Hail pommeled the roof during the severe thunderstorm yesterday

definitions: think about something carefully and thoroughly before making a decision
examples: She pondered the job offer for several days first
The philosopher pondered life's biggest questions in his writings

definitions: express opinions in a pompous way as if they were undeniably true
examples: He pontificates about politics though he rarely votes himself
The professor would pontificate for hours about obscure theories

definitions: make something understandable interesting or appealing to the general public
examples: The TV show popularised science for millions of young viewers
She popularised yoga in Western countries through her books

definitions: make something understandable interesting or appealing to the general public
examples: Carl Sagan popularized astronomy through his television series Cosmos
Social media helped popularize the new dance trend quickly

definitions: fill a place with people animals or plants as inhabitants
fill a database form or system with data or information
examples: European settlers populated the Americas over several centuries slowly
Wildlife has begun to populate the restored wetland area
The administrator will populate the database with customer information
The program automatically populates fields with default values

definitions: read or study something with great attention to detail and care
examples: Students pore over textbooks the night before final exams
She pored over the contract looking for hidden clauses

definitions: work as someone who carries luggage or goods for others
examples: He portered at the train station for twenty years
Students porter during summer to earn college tuition money

definitions: put forward or suggest an idea or theory as fact or basis for argument
examples: Scientists posit that climate change affects hurricane intensity significantly
The theory posits a connection between diet and mood

definitions: stamp mail with an official mark showing date and place of mailing
examples: The post office will postmark your letters with today's date
Make sure to postmark the application before the deadline

definitions: delay or put off an event or action to a later time or date
examples: We had to postpone the picnic because of rain
The meeting was postponed until all members could attend
